claim: In total, 27 were included within the narrative synthesis (please refer to Figure 1—Flow diagram of the review).
title: Figure 1.
caption: Flow diagram for scoping review process adapted from PRISMA statement by Tricco, Moher, and colleagues [29].

claim: The remaining ones were carried out in Europe—one in Portugal, two in the United Kingdom (UK), one from a partnership between the UK, Spain, Germany, and The Netherlands (please refer to Figure 2).
title: Figure 2.
caption: Absolute frequency of geographical location of studies included.

claim:
Open in a new tab
Absolute frequency of geographical location of studies included.As to the year of publication, the authors chose to consider more contemporary studies, between 2014 and 2024, finding twenty-seven relevant studies, two from 2013, one from 2015, four from 2017, one from 2018, three from 2019, three from 2020, one from 2021, four from 2022, two from 2023, and more recently, in 2024, six studies were identified as significant, showing a growing awareness of climate change as a public health issue—please refer to Figure 3.
title: Figure 3.
caption: Absolute frequency for publication year of included studies.

claim: Three papers aimed to provide for and evaluate sustainability exemplars in nursing settings (9,10,21), two focused on advocating for healthy learning environments and disaster nursing education, with a focus on nursing curricular preparedness (15,23), one aimed to add nurses‘ voices to the public and political discourse on CC (8), and one (26) aimed to investigate the effectiveness of CC mitigation strategies—please refer to Figure 4.
title: Figure 4.
caption: Absolute frequency for aims observed in studies included.

claim:
Population
As confirmed by Figure 5 presented below, the authors identified seventeen papers (1,7,11–13,15–25,27) that refer to nurses in general, with five studies (1,4,9,10,27) directed towards nurse lecturers and nurse educators and three to nurse leaders or coordinators (1,14,23), whilst all other papers targeted a population of ambulatory care nurses (2), health educators and promotors (26), pediatric nurses (8), public health nurses (5), or other advanced practice registered nurses (6).
title: Figure 5.
caption: Absolute frequency of population targeted by studies included.

claim: To revisit the review findings, please refer to Figure 6 below.
title: Figure 6.
caption: Summary evidence: overview of identified populations with corresponding contexts and type of interventions identified in urban areas.

claim: As to the year of publication, the authors chose to consider more contemporary studies, between 2014 and 2024, finding twenty-seven relevant studies, two from 2013, one from 2015, four from 2017, one from 2018, three from 2019, three from 2020, one from 2021, four from 2022, two from 2023, and more recently, in 2024, six studies were identified as significant, showing a growing awareness of climate change as a public health issue—please refer to Figure 3.
title: Figure 3.
caption: Absolute frequency for publication year of included studies.

claim: As confirmed by Figure 5 presented below, the authors identified seventeen papers (1,7,11–13,15–25,27) that refer to nurses in general, with five studies (1,4,9,10,27) directed towards nurse lecturers and nurse educators and three to nurse leaders or coordinators (1,14,23), whilst all other papers targeted a population of ambulatory care nurses (2), health educators and promotors (26), pediatric nurses (8), public health nurses (5), or other advanced practice registered nurses (6).
